urls.title: Tuberculosis, the Forgotten Pandemic
urls.description: Until COVID-19, tuberculosis killed more people each year than any other infectious disease. Its devastating toll—now on the rise—is increasingly fueled by mass incarceration.

urls.title: Prolonged cough for no reason can be the first sign of tuberculosis
urls.description: If you suddenly start coughing compulsively and seemingly for no reason, be sure to see your general practitioner or get an X-ray. This is one of the clearest and earliest symptoms of lung problems that tuberculosis causes. Of course, the cough can have other causes, such as seasonal allergies or dust allergies, but this is one case where it is better to be

urls.title: Tuberculosis Got to South America Through … Seals?
urls.description: Ancient DNA reveals unexpected twists in the history of this deadly disease.

tweets.text:
For a long time, it was believed that Europeans brought tuberculosis to the Americas, along with smallpox, measles, etc

But there are signs of TB in the Americas in bones  1000+ years old. An analysis of those bones suggests an unexpected culprit: seals 

https://t.co/t2zfDcQLm5

@lovedoveclarke If you were born ~ 1900 you'd have lived through
1906 SF Earthquake 
1914 WW1
1918 Spanish Flu
1920 Prohibition enacted
1929 Stock Market Crash / beginning of the Depression
1933 Prohibition repealed
1939 WW2
1945 Atomic bombing of Japan

And probably a lot of other bad stuff

tweets.text:
8/ Around 9 million people die every year of hunger and hunger-related diseases.

This is more than from AIDS, malaria, COVID and tuberculosis combined.

75% of them are children.

2.1 million people have already died from hunger in 2022 and we're still in March.

urls.title: Commemorate World Tuberculosis Day 2022
urls.description: "Invest to End TB. Save Lives"   Each year, we commemorate World Tuberculosis (TB) Day on March 24 to raise public awareness about the devastating health, social and economic consequences of TB, and to step up efforts to end the global TB epidemic. The date marks the day in 1882 when Dr Robert Koch announced that he had discovered the bacterium that causes TB, which opened the way towards diagnosing and curing this disease.

tweets.text: #Today in 1882, Robert Koch declared to the Berlin Physiological Society his discovery of the bacillus responsible for tuberculosis. On 24 March each year, World Tuberculosis Day is observed to raise awareness about the global epidemic of tuberculosis https://t.co/L7LMKrvDSa https://t.co/TmJEhr5TtN

Tuberculosis is one of the world’s deadliest infectious diseases. 

Canada has partnered with #TBREACH to strengthen the detection and treatment of #TB. https://t.co/t2NZBEkbu5
